Johnson]] |oclc=54014738}} : {{cite book |author=Coe, Michael D. |authorlink=Michael D. Coe |year=1994|origyear=1962 |title=Mexico: from the Olmecs to the Aztecs |publisher=[[Thames & Hudson]] |location=London and New York |edition=4th, Revised and Enlarged |isbn=0-500-27722-2 |oclc=29708907}} : {{cite book |author=Hassig, Ross |authorlink=Ross Hassig |year=2001 |title=Time, History, and Belief in Aztec and Colonial Mexico |location=Austin |publisher=[[University of Texas Press]] |isbn=0-292-73139-6 |oclc=44167649}} : {{cite journal|author=Hernández de León-Portilla, Ascención |year=2004 |title=Lenguas y escrituras mesoamericanas |url=http://arqueomex.com/S2N3nLENGUA70.html |journal=[[Arqueología mexicana]] |location=México, D.F. |publisher=[[Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia]], Editorial Raíces |issn=0188-8218 |volume=12 |issue=70 |pages=20–25 |accessdate=2008-05-14 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080515150042/http://www.arqueomex.com/S2N3nLENGUA70.html |archivedate=15 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |language=es }} :{{cite journal|author=Klein, Cecelia F. |year=2002 |title=La iconografía y el arte mesoamericano |url=http://arqueomex.com/S8N4ICONKlein55.pdf |format=PDF |journal=[[Arqueología mexicana]] |location=México, D.F. |publisher=[[Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia]], Editorial Raíces |issn=0188-8218 |volume=10 |issue=55 |pages=28–35 |accessdate= |language=es |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060103090214/http://www.arqueomex.com/S8N4ICONKlein55.pdf |archivedate=2006-01-03 |df= }} : {{cite book |author=León-Portilla, Miguel |authorlink=Miguel León-Portilla |year=1963 |title=Aztec Thought and Culture: A Study of the Ancient Náhuatl Mind |series=Civilization of the American Indian series, no. 67|others=Jack Emory Davis (trans.) |location=Norman |publisher=[[University of Oklahoma Press]] |oclc=181727}} : {{cite journal |author=Malmström, Vincent H. |authorlink=Vincent H. Malmström |date=1973-09-17 |title=Origin of the Mesoamerican 260-Day Calendar |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |location=Lancaster, PA |publisher=[[American Association for the Advancement of Science]]|volume=181 |issue=4103 |pages=939–941 |url=http://www.dartmouth.edu/~izapa/M-1.pdf |format=[[PDF]] Reprinted |doi=10.1126/science.181.4103.939|accessdate=2008-05-14 |pmid=17835843|bibcode = 1973Sci...181..939M | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080528152046/http://www.dartmouth.edu/~izapa/M-1.pdf| archivedate= 28 May 2008 | deadurl= no}} : {{cite book |author=Miller, Mary |authorlink=Mary Miller (art historian) |author2=Karl Taube |author2-link=Karl Taube |year=1993 |title=The Gods and Symbols of Ancient Mexico and the Maya: An Illustrated Dictionary of Mesoamerican Religion |publisher=[[Thames & Hudson]] |location=London |isbn=0-500-05068-6 |oclc=27667317}} : {{cite book |author=Prem, Hanns J. |authorlink=Hanns J. Prem | year=2008 | title= Manual de la antigua cronología Mexicana | publisher=[[Centro de Investigaciones y Estudios Superiores en Antropología Social]] | location=Mexico | isbn=978-968-496-694-9}} : {{cite book |author=Read, Kay Almere |year=1998 |title=Time and Sacrifice in the Aztec Cosmos |location=Bloomington |publisher=[[Indiana University Press]] |isbn=0-253-33400-4 |oclc=37909790}} : {{cite book |author=Sahagún, Bernardino de |authorlink=Bernardino de Sahagún |year=1950–82 |origyear=ca. 1540–85 |title=[[Florentine Codex|Florentine Codex: General History of the Things of New Spain]], 13 vols. in 12 |edition=translation of ''Historia General de las Cosas de la Nueva España'' |others=[[Charles E. Dibble]] and [[Arthur J. O. Anderson|Arthur J.O. Anderson]] (eds., trans., notes and illus.) |series=vols. I-XII |location=Santa Fe, NM and Salt Lake City |publisher=[[School of American Research]] and the [[University of Utah Press]] |isbn=0-87480-082-X |oclc=276351}} : {{cite book |author=Smith, Michael E. |authorlink=Michael E. Smith|year=2003 |title=The Aztecs |edition=2nd |publisher=[[Blackwell Publishing]] |location=Malden, MA |isbn=0-631-23015-7 |oclc=48579073}} : {{cite book |author=Tena, Rafael |year=2008 |title=El calendario mexica y la cronografía | location=Mexico |publisher=[[INAH]] | isbn=978-968-03-0293-2}} : {{cite book |author=Townsend, Richard F. |year=2000 |title=The Aztecs |edition=Revised 2nd |publisher=[[Thames & Hudson]] |location=London |isbn=0-500-28132-7 |oclc=43337963}} : {{cite web |author=Wimmer, Alexis |year=2006 |url=http://sites.estvideo.net/malinal/nahuatl.page.html |title=Dictionnaire de la langue nahuatl classique |format=online version, incorporating reproductions from {{lang|fr|Dictionnaire de la langue nahuatl ou mexicaine|italic=yes}} [1885], by [[Rémi Siméon]]|accessdate=}} {{fr icon}} {{nah icon}} : {{cite book |author=Zantwijk, Rudolph van |year=1985|title=The Aztec Arrangement: The Social History of Pre-Spanish Mexico |location=Norman |publisher=[[University of Oklahoma Press]] |isbn=0-8061-1677-3 |oclc=11261299 }} {{refend}} ==External links== *[http://www.ancient.eu/article/896/ The Aztec Calendar - Ancient History Encyclopedia] *{{es icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20070224213250/http://www.mna.inah.gob.mx/ Detailed description of the temalacatl] from Mexico's {{lang|es|[[Museo Nacional de Antropología]]|italic=no}} *[http://www.azteccalendar.com/ Daily Aztec Calendar] {{Calendars}} [[Category:Aztec society|Calendar]] [[Category:Aztec calendars| ]] [[Category:Aztec science and technology|Calendar]] [[Category:Obsolete calendars]]

revision.comment: 4 sentences in a row starting with "after"... must be a record.
revision.text:
{{one source|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox musical artist |name = Craig Smith |image = |image_size = |caption = |alt = |background = solo_singer |birth_name = Craig Vincent Smith |alias = Maitreya Kali, Satya Sai Maitreya Kali |birth_date = {{birth date|1945|4|25}} |birth_place = [[Los Angeles]], U.S. |death_date = {{death date and age|2012|3|16|1945|4|25}} |death_place = [[Los Angeles]], U.S. |genre = Pop, folk, rock |occupation = Musician, songwriter, actor |instrument = Guitar, voice |years_active = 1963–1972; sporadically to the late 1990s |label = [[Capitol Records]], Akashic Records, United Kingdom of America Records |associated_acts = The Good Time Singers, [[Andy Williams]], [[The Monkees]], The Penny Arkade }} '''Craig Vincent Smith''' (April 25, 1945 – March 16, 2012) was an [[Americans|American]] musician, songwriter and actor. He began his career in the 1960s playing pop and folk music and appearing on ''[[The Andy Williams Show]]''. After experimenting with drugs while travelling on the [[hippie trail]], he suffered mental health problems which worsened over time. He released two solo albums, ''Apache'' and ''Inca'', in the early 1970s under the names '''Maitreya Kali''' and '''Satya Sai Maitreya Kali'''. After spending nearly three years in prison for assaulting his mother, he spent the majority of the next 35 years homeless.
==Early and personal life== Smith was born in [[Los Angeles]],<ref name = "Stax13">Stax, p. 13</ref> the son of Charles "Chuck" Smith and Marguerite "Carole" Smith (née Lundquist).<ref name = "Stax15">Stax, p. 15</ref> His father was a descendant of gospel songwriter [[Charles H. Gabriel]].<ref>Stax, p, 14</ref> His mother was of Swedish and German descent.<ref name = "Stax15"/> Smith had two older brothers and one younger sister.<ref name = "Stax13"/> Chuck Smith had worked as a manager at the Jade Room, a nightclub owned by Larry Potter, and was known by the stage name Chuck Barclay.<ref>Stax, p. 16</ref> After World War Two he worked as a welder and a salesman.<ref>Stax, p. 24</ref> Chuck died in 1978, aged 64, from a stroke, and Carole died in 1998, aged 82, from pulmonary disease.<ref name = "Stax205">Stax, p. 205</ref>
Smith attended [[Grant High School (Los Angeles)|Grant High School]], becoming class president and being on the school gymnastics team.<ref>Stax, p. 26</ref> He graduated in June 1963, and turned down a number of offers from colleges in order to pursue a career in the entertainment industry.<ref>Stax, p. 27</ref>
==Career== ===1963–1966: the Good Time Singers=== In August 1963 Smith was recruited by [[Michael Storm]] and Tom Drake (who had performed together as the Other Singers) to join the Good Time Singers, a band formed to replace [[the New Christy Minstrels]] on ''[[The Andy Williams Show]]''.<ref>Stax, pp. 33–34</ref> From December 1963 to January 1964 Smith and Storm also performed shows with [[Gordon MacRae|Gordon]] and [[Sheila MacRae]], supported by their daughters [[Heather MacRae|Heather]] and [[Meredith MacRae|Meredith]].<ref>Stax, p. 42</ref> The Good Time Singers released their debut self-titled album in January 1964,<ref>Stax, p. 44</ref> and their second album ''One Step More'' in October 1964.<ref>Stax, p. 47</ref> In between the albums they had embarked on a 17-city tour.<ref>Stax. p. 46</ref> Around this time Smith began songwriting, and he wrote a song called "Christmas Holiday", which was recorded by [[Andy Williams]] for his 1965 album ''[[Merry Christmas (Andy Williams album)|Merry Christmas]]''.<ref>Stax, p. 53</ref> As the Good Times Singers' was ending, Smith and fellow bandmember Lee Montgomery intended to form a new duo called Craig & Lee, but Smith had to pull out after successfully auditioning for a new ABC television show,<ref>Stax, p. 54</ref> called ''The Happeners''.<ref>Stax, pp. 57–58</ref> Smith had previously unsuccessfully auditioned for ''[[The Monkees (TV series)|The Monkees]]''.<ref>Stax, p. 57</ref> The pilot for ''The Happeners'' was filmed in November 1965.<ref name = "Stax67">Stax, p. 67</ref> The Good Times Singers' contract for ''The Andy Williams Show'' was not renewed past 1966.<ref>Stax, p. 55</ref>
===1966–1967: ''The Happeners'' and Chris & Craig=== After a successful audition process, Smith won the role of Alan Howard on ''The Happeners''.<ref name = "Stax67"/> The show was to be directed by [[David Greene (director)|David Greene]],<ref>Stax, p. 68</ref> and was a mix of acting and singing, set in New York and based on the fictional eponymous folk trio.<ref>Stax, p. 69</ref> However, ABC declined to pick up the show following the pilot episode.<ref>Stax, p. 71</ref> Smith and his ''The Happeners'' co-star Chris Ducey decided to form a musical duo called Chris & Craig.<ref>Stax, p. 72</ref> They moved into an apartment together and began writing songs.<ref name = "Stax73">Stax, p. 73</ref> They signed to [[Capitol Records]], recording a number of demos throughout the summer of 1966.<ref name = "Stax74">Stax, p. 74</ref> Their first single, "Isha", was written by Ducey and released in July 1966.<ref name = "Stax74"/> Originally an acoustic duo,<ref name = "Stax73"/> during their later 1966 sessions they began experimenting with a full band,<ref>Stax pp. 74–75</ref> and in November 1966 they played a show supporting [[the Mothers of Invention]] with such a full band, with Smith and Ducey playing electric guitars.<ref name = "Stax76">Stax, p. 76</ref> Throughout late 1966 and early 1967 the duo continued to write and record more songs, but they were never released by the label.<ref name = "Stax76"/> In 1967 Smith befriended [[Gábor Szabó]] and [[the Beach Boys]], unsuccessfully offering to write songs for the latter.<ref>Stax, p. 79</ref> In early 1967 Chris & Craig began playing with a permanent backing band.<ref>Stax, p. 83</ref> Through their friendship with [[Michael Nesmith]] of the Monkees, they hired [[Jerry Perenchio]] as their manager.<ref name = "Stax88">Stax, p. 88</ref> They changed their name to the Penny Arcade, shortly becoming the Penny Arkade for trademark reasons.<ref name = "Stax88"/>
===1967–1968: the Penny Arkade=== Nesmith began producing Smith and Ducey, initially pairing them with [[John London]] (bass) and Johnny Raines (drums).<ref>Stax, p. 90</ref> They were eventually replaced by [[Donald F. Glut]] on bass (who had appeared in an earlier incarnation of the band) and Bobby Donaho on drums.<ref>Stax, p. 93</ref> While the band worked on their own material, Smith continued to write songs, including "Salesman" for the Monkees,<ref>Stax, p. 98</ref> and "Hands of the Clock" and "Lazy Sunny Day" for Heather MacRae.<ref>Stax, p. 99</ref> Smith was also credited as co-producer for the songs, alongside [[Bob Thiele]].<ref>Stax, p. 100</ref> He also wrote "[[Holly (song)|Holly]]" for Williams.<ref name = "Stax120">Stax, p. 120</ref> Nesmith took the band into a studio to record their album.<ref>Stax, p. 106</ref> One of the songs written at this time by Smith was "Country Girl", which was later recorded and released by [[Glen Campbell]] for his ''[[Try a Little Kindness]]'' album.<ref>Stax, p. 107</ref> The album never materialised, but some of the songs were collected and released as ''Not the Freeze'' in 2004.<ref>Stax, p. 105</ref> After a bad review of one of their live shows, the band decided to concentrate on writing and recording songs.<ref>Stax, pp. 111–112</ref> In early 1968 they unsuccessfully auditioned for the role of house band on the TV show ''[[Peyton Place (TV series)|Peyton Place]]''.<ref>Stax, p. 114</ref> In February 1968 Smith and his father went into business together, running a bar called the Buckeye Inn.<ref>Stax, p. 115</ref> In late 1968 Smith was associating with the [[Manson Family]], and exploring an interest in Eastern philosophy, particularly [[Transcendental Meditation]].<ref>Stax, pp. 116–117</ref> Smith eventually left the Penny Arkade and decided to go travelling.<ref>Stax, pp. 119–120</ref> The band continued without Smith until 1969, renamed as the Armadillo and with Bob Arthur as a replacement guitarist.<ref>Stax, pp. 135–137</ref>
===1968: travelling to Asia=== After previously smoking small amounts of [[marijuana]] with friends,<ref>Stax, p. 108</ref> Smith began experimenting with [[LSD]] in 1968.<ref name = "Stax120"/> During his travels Smith took LSD on a "regular" basis,<ref name = "Stax126">Stax, p. 126</ref> and he smoked "copious amounts of [[hashish]]" while in Afghanistan.<ref name = "Stax128">Stax, p. 128</ref> Smith decided to travel to India alone, with just a guitar and a backpack.<ref>Stax, p. 121</ref> He set off to join the [[hippie trail]], arriving in Turkey in October 1968, possibly via Austria and Greece.<ref>Stax, p. 123</ref> Smith met fellow Western travellers (an Irishman and two American women) in Istanbul, and they set off together in a VW van, intending to drive to Delhi.<ref>Stax, pp. 123–124</ref> After the van broke down, they hitched a ride in a lorry transporting olive oil,<ref>Stax, p. 124</ref> before taking a bus to Iran.<ref>Stax, p. 125</ref> They passed through Afghanistan,<ref name = "Stax126"/> with Smith deciding to leave his companions for a few days in [[Kandahar]] while they travelled on to [[Kabul]].<ref name = "Stax128"/> Smith never joined them in Kabul; when his companions returned to Kandahar a few months later, they heard rumours that he had "gone crazy", running through the market with a knife threatening people, and then disappeared.<ref>Stax, pp. 128–129</ref> It later became apparent that after threatening a market vendor, Smith had been beaten close to death and robbed, and possibly kidnapped and raped.<ref>Stax, p. 129</ref> Smith possibly spent some time in an Afghan insane asylum,<ref name = "Stax130">Stax, p. 130</ref> where he is thought to have developed acute [[schizophrenia]].<ref name="Our Existence 2018">The sleevenotes from the album, ''Love is Our Existence'' (Maitreya Apache Music, 2018).</ref> It is not known if Smith ever reached India, although he and his travelogue claims he did visit India and reconnected with the Maharishi and went to Nepal.<ref name = "Stax130"/><ref name="Our Existence 2018"/>
===1969–1970: return to United States and travelling to South America=== Smith returned to the United States in late 1968 or early 1969,<ref>Stax, p. 131</ref> initially living back with his parents.<ref>Stax, p. 140</ref> He was possibly institutionalized and medicated for a short period.<ref>Stax, p. 149</ref> By this stage he was using the name "Maitreya Kali",<ref>Stax, p. 132</ref> which he intended to become his legal name,<ref name = "Stax141">Stax, p. 141</ref> although this never happened until 1971.<ref name="Our Existence 2018"/> He continued to receive royalty checks from his historical songwriting for Williams and Campbell, amongst others.<ref>Stax, p. 142</ref> After his girlfriend left him, Smith decided to travel to South America, spending time in Peru, Ecuador, Bolivia, Argentina, and the Galapagos Islands of Chile.<ref>Stax, p. 143</ref> Returning from South America, Smith reunited with his girlfriend, and they became engaged.<ref>Stax, p. 144</ref> When the engagement ended, Smith ripped up the wedding dress his fiancée had chosen.<ref>Stax, p. 145</ref> Following another brief re-connection, the relationship ended for good when Smith violently threatened one of her male friends.<ref>Stax, p. 147</ref>
===1970–1971: deterioration in mental health=== Smith claimed to have mystical powers,<ref>Stax, p. 133</ref> and thought he was a messiah.<ref name = "Stax141"/> He prophesied that he would be "King of the World" by 2000.<ref>Stax, p. 161</ref> He claimed to be a reincarnation of Jesus, Buddha, and Hitler.<ref>Stax, p. 162</ref> As his erratic and bizarre behavior became more pronounced, such as claiming voices were telling him to kill people, his friends started to ignore him.<ref>Stax, pp. 149–150</ref> One friend eventually had to obtain a restraining order against Smith.<ref>Stax, p. 150</ref> His appearance became more and more unkempt, with long hair and a wild beard.<ref>Stax, p. 157</ref> At one point, he shaved his head and beard off, and dressed in robes, his appearance comparable to a Buddhist monk, although his hair and beard would later grow back.<ref name="Our Existence 2018"/> He visited Heather and Sheila MacRae in Miami, and was asked to leave by Sheila's new husband after he woke up to find Smith standing over their bed with a knife.<ref>Stax, p. 158</ref> Heather saw him again in Los Angeles in 1972, when he "looked really scary [...] just totally looked insane, and would say weird things."<ref>Stax, p. 159</ref>
===1971–1972: ''Apache'' and ''Inca''=== Smith wrote two solo albums ''Apache'' and ''Inca'' in 1971, which were self-released in 1972.<ref>Stax, p. 165</ref> In the liner notes to both albums, Smith claims to have played every instrument.<ref name = "Stax167">Stax, p. 167</ref> The liner notes as a whole have been described as "bizarre [and] rambling",<ref>Stax, p. 166</ref> and display his belief system.<ref>Stax, p. 166–167</ref> ''Apache'' was released on his own 'Akashic Records',<ref name = "Stax167"/> and features three songs from the Penny Arkade recording sessions.<ref>Stax, p. 168</ref> ''Inca'' was released a few months after ''Apache'', in the summer of 1972,<ref>Stax, p. 169</ref> not as a standalone album but as a double gatefold with ''Apache'' on his new 'United Kingdom of America Records' label.<ref>Stax, p. 170</ref> Like ''Apache'', ''Inca'' also features songs from the Penny Arkade recording sessions.<ref>Stax, p. 171</ref> The albums were mainly distributed to Smith's friends or sold on the street.<ref>Stax, p. 175</ref>
===1973–1976: prison=== After the albums were released, Smith sold his car with the intention of going to Ethiopia.<ref>Stax, p. 177</ref> His mental health problems continued, such as suggesting to a friend that they fight to the death using samurai swords.<ref>Stax, p. 180</ref> He also had a small black spider tattooed in the middle of his forehead in 1972 or 1973.<ref>Stax, p. 181</ref> On April 22, 1973, Smith attacked his mother at the family home.<ref>Stax, p. 183–184</ref> An attempted murder charge was not established,<ref>Stax, p. 186</ref> and following a psychiatric examination, he pleaded 'no contest' to a charge of assault.<ref>Stax, p. 188</ref> He was sentenced in November 1973 to six months to life, the maximum sentence for the offence, and the Judge suggested intense medical and psychiatric treatment.<ref>Stax, p. 189</ref> He began his sentence at the [[California Institution for Men]], before transferring to the [[Deuel Vocational Institution]] in December 1973.<ref>Stax, p. 193</ref> He transferred again, to the [[California Men's Colony]], in February 1974.<ref>Stax, p. 196</ref> He was granted parole at the fourth attempt, and was released from prison in June 1976.<ref>Stax, 197</ref>
===1977–2012: later years and death=== Suzannah Jordan, the third member of ''The Happeners'' trio, ran into Smith in LA in 1977; he was homeless but did not display any mental health issues.<ref>Stax, p. 200</ref> He has been drifting in and out of mental hospitals until the mid-1980s when funding was cut, and would then spend the next years homeless.<ref name="Our Existence 2018"/> He also had various run-ins with the law.<ref>Stax, p. 208–210</ref> In 1981 or 1982 he saw another old friend and told her he had been recording music.<ref>Stax, p. 201</ref> He has been indeed recording music, according to Mike Stax, as late as the late 1990s,<ref>[https://sites.lsa.umich.edu/living-writers/stax/] By Frank Uhle, "Living Writers - Mike Stax". [[University of Michigan]] 2017.</ref> which includes the 1994 song "Waves", which was released on the 2018 CD version of the album Love is Our Existence.<ref>Craig Smith. ''Love is Our Existence'' (Maitreya Apache Music, 2018).</ref> By the early 2000s his "ramblings" had moved from Eastern philosophy/his Maitreya Kali persona to aliens.<ref name = "Stax205"/> Smith died on March 16, 2012.<ref>Stax, p. 215</ref> His family declined to collect his ashes,<ref>Stax, p. 218</ref> and they were eventually collected by journalist Mike Stax.<ref>Stax, pp. 223–224</ref>
==Discography==
===With The Penny Arkade===
*''Not the Freeze'' (Recorded in 1967-68) ([[Sundazed Records|Sundazed]], 2004)
===Studio Albums===
*''Apache'' (Released under the name Satya Sai Maitreya Kali) (Akashic Records, 1971) *''Inca'' (Released under the name Satya Sai Maitreya Kali) (United Kingdom of America Records, 1972) *''Love is Our Existence'' (Maitreya Apache Music, 2018)<ref>Posthumous release of his demos, ranging from 1966-1971, except the CD bonus track Waves which was recorded in 1994.</ref>
==Sources== *{{cite book|title=Swim Through the Darkness: My Search for Craig Smith and the Mystery of Maitreya Kali|last=Stax|first=Mike|publisher=Process Media|year=2016|isbn=9781934170656}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Smith, Craig}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:American male singer-songwriters]] [[Category:American singer-songwriters]] [[Category:American male actors]] [[Category:American male criminals]] [[Category:American criminals]] [[Category:People with schizophrenia]] [[Category:Outsider musicians]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.5beta)

revision.text:
[[Image:Lifetime prevalence of incarceration.svg|right|thumb|300px|As of 2001, the likelihood of going to prison in percentages for various demographic groups in the United States.]]
The '''criminal stereotype of African Americans in the United States''' is an [[ethnic stereotype]] according to which [[African American]] males in particular are stereotyped to be dangerous criminals.<ref>[[Shaun L. Gabbidon|Gabbidon, Shaun L.]] (ed.); Greene, Helen Taylor (ed.); Young, Vernetta D. (ed.). (2001). [https://books.google.com/books?id=zvcwLjy8C1sC&pg=PA349&dq=%22criminal+black+man%22&hl=en&ei=FAl7TK_eOsGsOOO2uacG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22criminal%20black%20man%22&f=false ''African American Classics in Criminology and Criminal Justice'']. [[SAGE Publications]]. p. 349. {{ISBN|978-0-7619-2433-3}}.</ref><ref>Edles, Laura Desfor (2002). [https://books.google.com/books?id=JWmcI25LoRUC&pg=PA124&dq=criminal+black+man+edles&hl=en&ei=8xmRTJzZIIPAswaE9PS1AQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Cultural Sociology in Practice'']. [[Wiley-Blackwell]]. p. 124. {{ISBN|978-0-631-21090-0}}.</ref> The figure of the African-American man as criminal has appeared frequently in [[American popular culture]]<ref>Tucker, p. 4.</ref><ref>Vera, Harnan; Feagin, Joe R. (2007). [https://books.google.com/books?id=7Q93YGc6kngC&pg=PA125&dq=Vera+feagin+black+people&hl=en&ei=OBqRTOP_MpGCswbo-I21AQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Vera%20feagin%20black%20people&f=false ''Handbook of the Sociology of Racial and Ethnic Relations'']. [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]]. p. 125. {{ISBN|978-0-387-70844-7}}.</ref><ref>Russell-Brown, p. 77.</ref> and has been associated with consequences in the justice system such as [[racial profiling]] and harsher sentences for African American defendants in trials.
==African Americans and crime statistics== In 2016 92% of interacial crimes in the US were committed by African Americans against whites but African Americans are most likely to be overrepresented in arrests. For example, in 1993, African Americans comprised 31 percent of total arrests yet constituted 12 percent of the population. A study found that in 1979, 80% of the racial disparity in prison populations was accounted for by African Americans committing more crime, but by 2008, another study by [[Michael Tonry]] and Matthew Melewski found that this percentage had decreased to 61%.<ref>{{cite journal|date=19 August 2011|title=Addressing Racial Disparities in Incarceration|journal=The Prison Journal|volume=91|issue=3 Suppl|pages=87S–101S|doi=10.1177/0032885511415227|last1=Mauer|first1=M.}}</ref>
=== Incarceration for violent crimes === In 1994, African Americans accounted for between 45 percent and 50 percent of crimes for murder, rape, robbery, and aggravated assault. In general, African Americans are approximately six times more likely to be arrested for violent crimes than are whites. African Americans are also most overrepresented in robbery in 1993, comprising 62 percent of arrestees. African Americans accounted for 52.5% of homicide offenders from 1980 to 2008, with whites 45.3% and "Other" 2.2%. The offending rate for blacks was almost 8 times higher than whites while blacks account for less than 15% of people living in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjs.gov/content/pub/pdf/htus8008.pdf|title=Homicide Trends in the United States, 1980-2008|page=3}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Homicide Trends in the United States, 1980-2008|last=Cooper|first=Alexia|year=2012|isbn=1249573246|page=3}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/homicides-fall-to-lowest-rate-in-four-decades-133967273.html|title=Homicides Fall to Lowest Rate in Four Decades}}</ref>
=== Incarceration for drug related crimes === For drug related offenses, from 1965 through the early 1980s, African Americans were approximately twice as likely as whites to be arrested. However, with the [[War on Drugs]] in the 1970s, African American arrest rates skyrocketed, while white arrest rates increased only slightly. By the end of the 1980s, African Americans were more than five times more likely than whites to be arrested for drug-related offenses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bjs.gov/ucrdata/|title=UCR Statistics|last=Department of Justice|first=|date=1993|website=|access-date=}}</ref> Blumstein argues that as national self-report data showed that drug use was actually declining among both African Americans and Whites, it is highly unlikely that these race differences in arrest rates represent "real" patterns of drug use. Instead these crime statistics reflect the government's targeting of only specific types of drug use and trafficking.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Blumstein|first=Alfred|year=1993|title=Making Rationality Relevant|url=|journal=Criminology|volume=31|pages=|via=|doi=10.1111/j.1745-9125.1993.tb01119.x}}</ref> Furthermore, although the "black drug user" stereotype is heavily associated with young African Americans, a recent survey using self-reported data found African American young people less likely to use illegal drugs than other racial groups in the U.S.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://healthland.time.com/2011/11/07/study-whites-more-likely-to-abuse-drugs-than-blacks|title=Study: Whites More Likely to Abuse Drugs Than Blacks | TIME.com|last=Szalavitz|first=Maia|date=2011-11-07|publisher=Healthland.time.com|accessdate=2015-02-24}}</ref> [[Michelle Alexander]] furthers the argument that the disproportionate mass incarceration of African Americans in drug-related offenses is caused by racial bias within the criminal justice system, terming this phenomenon as "[[The New Jim Crow]]", in a book of the same name. Alexander claims that racial beliefs and stereotypes as a direct result of a media saturated with images of black criminals have obviously and predictably created a sharp disparity in the rates at which blacks and whites are subject to encounters with law enforcement.
=== Statistics and self-reporting === Scholars have argued that these official arrest statistics do not fully reflect actual criminal behavior as the criminal stereotype that African Americans hold influences the decisions to make arrests. Specifically, because the stereotype of African American is pervasive and embedded in society, police officers unconsciously believe that African Americans are dangerous and are therefore more likely to arrest African Americans.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Jail: Managing the Underclass in American Society|last=Irwin|first=John|publisher=University of California Press|year=1985|isbn=978-0520277342|location=|pages=}}</ref>
Instead, [[Self-report study|self-reporting]] crime statistics have been used to overcome the criticism that the official arrest statistics are biased. Many studies found little or no differences in self-reported offending among juveniles of different racial and ethnic group, with some scholars suggesting that [[Institutional racism|institutionalized racism]] within the criminal justice system is the cause for the disproportionate arrest rates of African Americans.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sampson et al.|first=|year=1997|title=Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Crime and Criminal Justice in the United States|url=https://dash.harvard.edu/bitstream/handle/1/3226952/Sampson_RacialEthnicDisparities.pdf?sequence=2|journal=Crime and Justice|volume=21|pages=|via=}}</ref> However, Hindelang found that black males were least likely to self-report offenses recorded by the police, with 33 percent of total offenses and 57 percent of serious offenses known to police not being self-reported by African American males,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hindelang|first=Michael|year=1981|title=Variations in Sex-Race-Age-Specific Incidence Rates of Offending|url=|journal=American Sociological Review|volume=46|pages=|via=|doi=10.2307/2095265}}</ref> suggesting some caution in concluding that self reported crime statistics accurately portray the actual rate of crime behavior.
==History== According to some scholars, the stereotype of African Americans males as criminals was first constructed as a tool to "discipline" and control slaves during the time of [[slavery in the United States]]. For instance, Amii Barnard alleges that out of fear of the [[Fugitive slaves in the United States|fugitive slaves]] staging a rebellion, slaveholders sought to spread the stereotype that African American males were dangerous criminals who would rape the "innocent" and "pure" white women if they had the opportunity to.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Barnard|first=Amii|year=1993|title=Application of critical race feminism to the anti-lynching movement: Black women's fight against race and gender ideology|url=http://escholarship.org/uc/item/1kc308xf|journal=UCLA Women's Law Journal|volume=3|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=The African-American atlas: Black history and culture—An illustrated reference|last=Asante et al.|first=|publisher=Macmillan|year=1998|isbn=978-0028649849|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> A law introduced in Pennsylvania in 1700 illustrates the fear of a dangerous African American man within the slaveholding society- it mandated that should a black man attempt to rape a White woman, the perpetrator will be castrated or punished to death.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The statutes at large of Pennsylvania from 1682 to 1801|publisher=State of Pennsylvania|year=1896|isbn=|location=Harrisburg|pages=}}</ref>
Carter et al. argues that this criminal stereotype contributed to [[lynching in the United States]] that mostly targeted African American males in the south.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Carter et al.|first=|year=2017|title=You Can’t Fix What You Don’t Look At: Acknowledging Race in Addressing Racial Discipline Disparities|url=http://journals.sagepub.com.proxy.lib.umich.edu/doi/pdf/10.1177/0042085916660350|journal=Urban Education|volume=52|pages=|via=SAGE|doi=10.1177/0042085916660350}}</ref> [[Ida B. Wells]], the well-known anti-lynching activist published the pamphlet entitled the "Southern Horrors: Lynch Law in All Its Phases" from 1892-1920 reporting that contrary to the notion that lynchings occurred because African American males had sexually abused or attacked white women, fewer than 30% of reported lynchings even involved the charge of rape. She also followed up with an editorial that suggested that, most sexual liaisons between black men and white women were consensual and illicit.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gildedage.lib.niu.edu/wellspamphlets|title=The Anti-Lynching Pamphlets of Ida B. Wells, 1892-1920|last=Schechter|first=Patricia|date=|website=Illinois During the Gilded Age|access-date=}}</ref> The criminal stereotype of African Americans as potential rapists at that time is also illustrated in the controversial media portrayal of African American men in the 1915 American epic film, [[The Birth of a Nation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.themovingarts.com/revered-and-reviled-d-w-griffiths-the-birth-of-a-nation/|title=Revered and Reviled: D.W. Griffith’s 'The Birth of a Nation'|last=Armstrong|first=Eric|date=|website=The Moving Arts Film Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529224316/http://themovingarts.com/revered-and-reviled-d-w-griffiths-the-birth-of-a-nation/|archive-date=2010-05-29|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref>
According to [[Marc Mauer]] however, although African Americans have been consistently stereotyped as "biologically flawed" individuals who have a general tendency towards crime, the depiction of African Americans as criminals became more threatening only in the 1970s and early 1980s- with the evolution of the stereotype of African American males as "petty thieves" to "ominous criminal predators".<ref>{{Cite book|title=Race to incarcerate|last=Marc|first=Mauer|publisher=The New Press|year=1999|isbn=978-1-59558-022-1|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> In the late 1990s, Melissa Hickman Barlow argued that the perception of African American males as criminals was so entrenched in society that she said “talking about crime is talking about race”.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Barlow|first=Melissa|year=1998|title=Race and the Problem of Crime in 'Time' and 'Newsweek' Cover Stories, 1946 to 1995|journal=Social Justice|volume=25|pages=149–183|jstor=29767075}}</ref> Between 2005 and 2015, the gap in the incarceration rate between blacks and whites declined while still remaining high. The rate of incarceration for blacks declined -2.0% per year, for Hispanics it declined -2.3% per year while for whites it declined only -0.1% per year. Blacks today continue to be incarcerated at a rate over 2.1 times Hispanics and 5.6 times whites.<ref>https://www.bjs.gov/content/pub/pdf/p15.pdf</ref> The disparity varies widely by state and region.
==Perceptions== [[Katheryn Russell-Brown]] in her book ''[[The Color of Crime (1998 book)|The Color of Crime: Racial Hoaxes, White Fear, Black Protectionism, Police Harassment and Other Macroaggressions]]'' (1998) refers to the stereotype as the "criminal black man", because people associate young black men with crime in American culture. She writes that the black male is portrayed as a "symbolic pillager of all that is good".<ref>Russell-Brown, p. 84.</ref> Russell-Brown refers to the criminal black man as a myth<ref>Russell-Brown, p. 114.</ref><ref>See, Letha A. Lee (2001). [https://books.google.com/books?id=8kqFuOgvV2IC&pg=PA14&dq=%22criminal+black+man%22&hl=en&ei=vMSFTOKwDdHMswaAyN2aBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEgQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22criminal%20black%20man%22&f=false ''Violence as Seen Through a Prism of Color'']. [[Haworth Press]]. p. 14. {{ISBN|0-7890-1393-2}}</ref> and suggests that the stereotype contributes to "[[racial hoax]]es". She defines these as "when someone fabricates a crime and blames it on another person because of his race OR when an actual crime has been committed and the perpetrator falsely blames someone because of his race".<ref>Russell-Brown, pp. 70–71.</ref> Stuart Henry and Mark Lanier in ''What Is Crime?: Controversies Over the Nature of Crime and What to Do about It'' (2001) refer to the criminal black man as a "mythlike race/gender image of deviance".<ref>Henry, Stuart; Lanier, Mark. (2001). [https://books.google.com/books?id=2l36DmN5r10C&pg=PA159&dq=%22criminal+black+man%22&hl=en&ei=ff56TL7AApOZONzbmJUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CF0Q6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=%22criminal%20black%20man%22&f=false ''What Is Crime?: Controversies Over the Nature of Crime and What to Do about It'']. [[Rowman & Littlefield]]. p. 159. {{ISBN|0-8476-9807-6}}.</ref>
===Perpetuation of negative images by popular culture=== Linda G. Tucker in ''Lockstep and Dance: Images of black Men in Popular Culture'' (2007) argues that the representations in popular culture of criminal African American men help perpetuate the image.<ref>Tucker, p. 5.</ref> She writes that the portrayal of crime by conservative politicians during heated campaigns is used as a metaphor for race: they have recast fears about race as fears about crime.<ref>Tucker, p. 8.</ref> For instance, Republican opponents of Dukakis used the case of [[Willie Horton]] to attack the Democrat's stand on law enforcement, suggesting that people would be safer if led by Republicans. She says that such politicians used Horton as a collective symbol of African American male criminality.<ref>Tucker, pp. 8–9.</ref>
The criminal African American man appears often in the context of athletics and sports. Arthur A. Raney and Jennings Bryant discuss this in ''Handbook of Sports and Media'' (2006). They cite ''Beyond the Cheers: Race as Spectacle in College Sport'' (2001) by C. Richard King and Charles Fruehling Springwood,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a_xNaX8QqMIC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Beyond the Cheers: Race as Spectacle in College Sport - C. Richard King, Charles Fruehling Springwood - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-02-24}}</ref> which examines the connection between race, crime, and sports. They study the ways in which "criminality indelibly marks the African American athlete". Raney and Bryant says coverage and reception of accusations of crimes by sportspeople differed depending on the race of the individual.<ref name=Raney531>Raney, Arthur A.; Bryant, Jennings. (2006). [https://books.google.com/books?id=sC3TGxZplK4C&pg=PA533&dq=criminal+black+man+popular+culture&hl=en&ei=HQt7TNuNBYTuOcbnpO4G&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CEEQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Handbook of Sports and Media'']. [[Taylor & Francis|Lawrence Erlbaum Associates]]. p. 531. {{ISBN|0-8058-5189-5}}.</ref>
[[John Milton Hoberman]] in ''Darwin's Athletes: How Sport Has Damaged black America and Preserved the Myth of Race'' (1997) blames entertainment and advertising industries for propagating the negative stereotypes, namely, for "the merger of the athlete, the [[gangster rapper]], and the criminal into a single black male persona ... into the predominant image of black masculinity in the United States and around the world", which has harmed racial integration.<ref>[[John Milton Hoberman|Hoberman, John Milton]] (1997). [https://books.google.com/books?id=gF6-YAWoYAYC&pg=PR27&dq=darwin%27s+athletes+gangster+rapper,+and+the+criminal&hl=en&ei=3Rt7TIHfLY3KOOWIgbkG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Darwin's Athletes: How Sport Has Damaged Black America and Preserved the Myth of Race'']. [[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]]. p. xxvii. {{ISBN|0-395-82292-0}}.</ref>
A number of studies have concluded that the [[news]] systematically portrays black Americans as criminals and whites as victims of the crime.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Entman|first=Robert|year=1992|title=BLACKS IN THE NEWS: TELEVISION, MODERN RACISM AND CULTURAL CHANGE|url=http://www.aejmc.org/home/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Journalism-Quarterly-1992-Entman-341-611.pdf|journal=Journalism Quarterly|volume=69|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Entman|first=Robert|year=1994|title=Representation and reality in the portrayal of Blacks on network television news.|url=|journal=Journalism Quarterly|volume=71|pages=509–520|via=|doi=10.1177/107769909407100303}}</ref> For example, a study found that in news programs broadcast in the [[Los Angeles]] area, blacks were overly represented as perpetrators of crime and underrepresented as victims of crimes on television news, compared to actual crime statistics. This is in stark contrast to how, compared to actual crime statistics, whites were found to be underrepresented as perpetrators and overrepresented as victims of crime in television news stories.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dixon|first=Travis|year=2000|title=Overrepresentation and Underrepresentationof African Americans and Latinos as Lawbreakers on Television News|url=|journal=Journal of Communication|volume=|pages=131–151|via=|doi=10.1093/joc/50.2.131}}</ref>
A study examining the news reports from ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'', ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' and ''[[USA Today]]'' covering the effects of [[Hurricane Katrina]] showed that in 80% of the time black evacuees were portrayed in photographs, the word "looting" was mentioned in the captions, suggesting that the black evacuees were criminals.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sommers et al.|first=|year=2006|title=Race and media coverage of Hurricane Katrina: Analysis, implications, and future research questions|url=|journal=Analyses of Social Issues and Public Policy|volume=6|pages=39–55|via=|doi=10.1111/j.1530-2415.2006.00103.x}}</ref>
==Consequences== There is evidence that the American society has internalized the criminal stereotype of African Americans. For example, in experiments where African American and white individuals perform the same act, respondents have reported that the black figure is more threatening than the white figure.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Duncan|first=Birt|year=1976|title=Differential social perception and attribution of intergroup violence: Testing the lower limits of stereotyping of Blacks.|url=http://psycnet.apa.org/psycinfo/1977-21139-001|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=34|pages=|via=|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.34.4.590}}</ref> Likewise, in surveys asking about fear of strangers in hypothetical situations, respondents are more fearful of being victimized by black strangers than by white strangers.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=St. John|first=Craig|year=1995|title=Fear of Black strangers|url=http://psycnet.apa.org/psycinfo/1996-93292-001|journal=Social Science Research|volume=24|pages=|via=|doi=10.1006/ssre.1995.1010}}</ref>
In other research, whites have been found to overestimate the differences between the rates at which whites and blacks commit some crimes. A 2012 study found that white Americans overestimated the percent of burglaries, illegal drug sales, and juvenile crimes committed by blacks by between 6.6 and 9.5 percentage points.<ref>{{cite journal|last2=CHIRICOS|first2=TED|last3=GOLDEN|first3=KRISTIN M.|last4=GERTZ|first4=MARC|date=February 2012|title=RECONSIDERING THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN PERCEIVED NEIGHBORHOOD RACIAL COMPOSITION AND WHITES’ PERCEPTIONS OF VICTIMIZATION RISK: DO RACIAL STEREOTYPES MATTER?*|journal=Criminology|volume=50|issue=1|pages=145–186|doi=10.1111/j.1745-9125.2011.00255.x|last1=PICKETT|first1=JUSTIN T.}}</ref>
There is also some research suggesting that blacks have also internalized the criminal stereotype. According to a study, 82% of blacks think they are perceived as violent by Whites.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sigelman|first=|year=1997|title=Metastereotypes: Blacks’ perceptions of Whites’ stereotypes of Blacks|url=|journal=Public Opinion Quarterly|volume=61|pages=|via=|doi=10.1086/297788}}</ref> African Americans are also more likely than Whites to think that racial profiling is widespread<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/12406/Racial-Profiling-Seen-Pervasive-Unjust.aspx|title=Racial profiling seen as pervasive, unjust.|last=Carlson|first=|date=|website=Gallup|access-date=}}</ref> and to think they are treated unfairly by police, both in general and in actual criminal justice encounters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/8389/Americans-See-Racial-Profiling-Widespread.aspx|title=Americans see racial profiling as widespread|last=Ludwig|first=|date=|website=Gallup|access-date=}}</ref>
===Consequences in the justice system=== Many psychologists argue that the cultural stereotype of black criminality can have an unconscious but substantial influence on the way that "people perceive individuals, process information, and form judgments".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Devine|first=Patricia|year=1989|title=Stereotypes and Prejudice: Their Automatic and Controlled Components|url=http://web.comhem.se/u52239948/08/devine89.pdf|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=56|pages=|via=|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.56.1.5}}</ref> For example, the criminal stereotype of African Americans could contribute to the reason behind why blacks are disproportionately more likely than Whites to be targeted by the police as suspects,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Weich|first=Ronald|year=2000|title=Justice on Trial: Racial Disparities in the American Criminal Justice System, Executive Summary|url=http://www.asca.net/system/assets/attachments/765/Racial_Disparities_in_the_American_Criminal_Justice_System.pdf|journal=Citizen's Commission on Civil Rights|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> interrogated<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Feld|first=|year=1997|title=Police interrogation of juveniles: An empirical study of policy and practice|url=|journal=The Journal of Criminal Law and Criminology|volume=96|pages=|via=}}</ref> and wrongfully convicted.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Wrongly convicted: Perspectives on failed justice|last=Parker|first=|publisher=|year=2001|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> The stereotype of a criminal African American has also been associated with [[racial profiling]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Welch|first=Kelly|year=2007|title=Black Criminal Stereotypes and Racial Profiling|url=http://journals.sagepub.com.proxy.lib.umich.edu/doi/pdf/10.1177/1043986207306870|journal=Journal of Contemporary Criminal Justice|volume=23|pages=276–288|via=|doi=10.1177/1043986207306870}}</ref>
In addition, a report from the U.S. Sentencing Commission stated that the sentences of black men were on average 19.5% longer than the sentences of white men from December 2007 to September 2011. Although the report did not attribute racism to the difference in sentencing decisions, the report did write that the judges “make sentencing decisions based on many legitimate considerations that are not or cannot be measured.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allgov.com/news/controversies/prison-sentences-for-black-men-are-20-percent-longer-than-those-for-white-men-for-same-crimes-130220?news=847124|title=Controversies - Prison Sentences for Black Men Are 20% Longer Than Those for White Men for Same Crimes - AllGov - News|date=2013-02-20|publisher=AllGov|author=|accessdate=2015-02-24}}</ref> Another similar study examining 58,000 federal criminal cases concluded that African-Americans’ jail time was almost 60% longer than white sentences while black men were on average more than twice as likely to face a mandatory minimum charge as white men were, even after taking into account arrest offense, age and location.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allgov.com/news/top-stories/black-americans-given-longer-sentences-than-white-americans-for-same-crimes?news=843984#.tzalfkfg6ey.facebook|title=Top Stories - Black Americans Given Longer Sentences than White Americans for Same Crimes - AllGov - News|date=2012-02-04|publisher=AllGov|accessdate=2015-02-24}}</ref> Although some scholars say this discrepancy is due to them being repeat offenders, others state that this is partially due to prosecutors over-charging African American defendants in contrast to white defendants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fjc.gov/public/pdf.nsf/lookup/NSPI201213.pdf/$file/NSPI201213.pdf|title=Program in Law & Economics Working Paper Series|publisher=Fjc.gov|accessdate=2013-08-18}}</ref> Supporting the latter claim, in [[mock trial]]s that experimentally manipulate the race of the defendant, respondents have been found to give African-American defendants harsher judgments of guilt and punishment than white defendants in otherwise identical cases.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sweeney|first=Laura|year=1992|title=The influence of race on sentencing: A meta-analytic review of experimental studies|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/bsl.2370100204/abstract|journal=Behavioral Sciences and The Law|volume=10|pages=|via=|doi=10.1002/bsl.2370100204}}</ref> Similarly, Giliam found that exposure to African American rather than White suspects led to increased support for [[capital punishment]] and the three-strikes legislation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Giliam|first=Franklin|year=2000|title=Prime Suspects: The Influence Of Local Television News On The Viewing Public|url=https://pcl.stanford.edu/common/docs/research/gilliam/1999/primesuspects.pdf|journal=American Journal of Political Science|volume=44|pages=|via=|doi=10.2307/2669264}}</ref>
Joseph Rand also suggests that when black witnesses are on trial with white jurors, they are more likely to feel [[stereotype threat]] and are more likely to appear less credible. To elaborate, because black witnesses are aware of the stereotype relating them as criminals, they are more motivated to control their behavior to counter stereotypes and appear truthful. However, because they try so hard to appear credible, they appear more anxious and unnatural, and therefore less credible to jurors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rand|first=Joseph|year=2000|title=The demeanor gap: Race, lie detection, and the jury.|url=|journal=Connecticut Law Review|volume=33|pages=1–61.|via=}}</ref>
===Social consequences=== Lincoln and Devah argue that the criminal stereotype of African American males can explain the growing [[racial segregation in the United States]]. Specifically, they found that the percentage of young black men in a neighborhood is correlated with the respondent's perceptions of neighborhood crime level, even after taking into account measures of actual crime rates and other neighborhood characteristics. This could explain why other races avoid areas with many black men, as the area is perceived to be dangerous.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Quillian|first=|year=2001|title=Black Neighbors, Higher Crime? The Role of Racial Stereotypes in Evaluations of Neighborhood Crime|jstor=10.1086/338938|journal=American Journal of Sociology|volume=107|pages=}}</ref>
Another study found that after [[Priming (psychology)|priming]] the "black criminal" stereotype among respondents (by exposing them to photographs of blacks appearing to plunder after [[Hurricane Katrina]]), the respondents reduced policy support for black evacuees-in-need but did not influence responses towards white evacuees-in-need.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Johnson|first=James|year=2009|title=Priming Media Stereotypes Reduces Support for Social Welfare Policies: The Mediating Role of Empathy|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/0146167208329856|journal=PERSONALITY AND SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGY|volume=35|pages=|via=|doi=10.1177/0146167208329856}}</ref>
===Consequences in other countries=== The criminal stereotype of black individuals is not just limited to the United States. One study administered a survey to [[Canadians]] showed that they believed African Canadians are more likely to commit crime, with nearly half of the respondents believing that 65% of black people committed more crimes than other racial groups in Canada.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Henry|first=Frances|year=1996|title=Perceptions of race and crime in Ontario: Empirical evidence from Toronto and the Durham region|url=|journal=Canadian Journal of Criminology|volume=38|pages=469–476|via=}}</ref> A working group of [[human rights]] experts from the [[United Nations]] has also expressed concerns that anti-African Canadian systemic racism is rampant in the Canadian justice system, especially in the arbitrary use of racial profiling.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=UN Expert Panel Warns of Systemic Anti-Black Racism in Canada's Criminal Justice System|last=UN News Service New York|first=|date=2016|work=AllAfrica.com|access-date=}}</ref>
Rahier argues that [[Afro-Ecuadorian]]s have been consistently stereotyped to be dangerous criminals in the popular and widely circulated magazine Vistazo, since the late 1950s. Similarly, he also argues that when race is mentioned in reporting of a crime in Ecuador's daily newspapers, the criminal was always black and the victim was always not black.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rahier|first=|year=1998|title=Blackness, the Racial/Spatial Order, Migrations, and Miss Ecuador 1995-96|journal=American Anthropologist|volume=100|pages=421–430|doi=10.1525/aa.1998.100.2.421|jstor=683121}}</ref>

For a copy, see [https://web.archive.org/web/20110516032759/http://www.northwestern.edu/ipr/publications/papers/2003/pagerquillianajs.pdf here]. * Rome, Dennis (2004).
